text: Aroma is fruit/berries and dark malts/a hint of acidity. The flavor is dark malts, fruit, chocolate and an acidic/slightly spicy finish.

At a tasting, many thanks, opaque black color, smallish creamy head, aroma of roasted coffee, composte, vanila and dark chocolate, aromatic roasted coffee flavor with earthy notes and bitter dark chocolate lingering to a mellow aftertaste, very nicely balanced. Really nice and satisfying.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Tom. Pours beautiful, deep brown-black with a tan head. Lots of chocolate, molasses, coffee, roasted beans in the nose. Sweet, roasted, dark chocolate, espresso, vanilla, finish is moderately bitter,alcohol is well hidden, rich flavors. Full-bodied, oily, smooth. Great beer, complex and rich, feels more like a good Imperial Porter

Can sample at a tasting at zvsns place. Thanks Tom. Deep black with brown head. The aroma has notes of dark chocolate, coffee, some nuts, almonds, some roastiness and alcohol. Bitter flavor with lots of coffee, dark chocolate, nuts, hoppy, oily, some roastiness, alcoholic. Full-bodied. Very good.

16floz can, no freshness date present, bought about six months ago for ~$9 a four-pack, last one out, poured into a mug glass. Blackish-brown in appears and a huge head amasses, then resides giving off a molasses aroma. A heavy, moderately robust, semi-sweet porter. Noted flavors are fig, tobacco, brown sugar, bark, and old coffee. This was perhaps a little better a few months back, as is its just okay.

Can, didnt write down the date, drunk 12/17/16 (it was refrigerated).Dark coal-brown body shows good clarity and magenta edges. Big, light tan head shows moderate to moderately-strong retention.Strong roast, chocolate and light vanilla with even a touch of green, pine and grapefruit-tinged hops.Clean, very prototypical porter notes of chocolate, strong roast and vanilla, with a malty texture, good attenuation (leans somewhat sweet) and lots of caramel lingering. Light to moderate carbonation, clean, with no alcohol.

Can. Black with a tan head. Roasty, caramel, sherry, some toffee aroma. Prune, coffee bitterness/ sourness, lots of roastiness in the mouth. full body, fairly carbonated, bitter and roasty and a little dry finish. Nice.

Opaque black with a tall dark tan head, recedling slowly leaving connected lacing. Smokey aroma with mocha, not too strong. Moderate to on the thin side feel. Initial taste is smokey, mocha, with bittering beginning right away and carrying throuh, with a nice bitter finish. The bittering lingers into the aftertaste. This is a very enjoyable beer. The taste is nicely balanced between the smokey malts and the bittering hops, it has a mix of flavors (chocolate, coffee, roasty/smokey malts) that blend together into a very enjoyable whole.

Black color with a big mocha head. Aroma of roast, coffee, chocolate, caramel, and licorice. Taste very rich, chocolaty, roasty and with loads of black coffee. This tastes more like and imperial stout than a porter. And a damn good one at that.

Can shared at a tasting at Naamas place. Better Beer Of The Month Club. Black with a nice light brown head. Great aroma full of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, roast, light soy sauce. Sweet flavor, slightly bitterish, with roast, cocoa, caramel, chocolate, some coffee, a bit of ash, a bit of alcohol, and a bitter finish. Medium to full-bodied, rounded mouthfeel. Very good.
Tallboy can from The Malt Shoppe, 9/25/16. Inky dark brown, large foamy brown head, good retention. Aroma of roasted malts and dark fruits. The taste matches. Thin bodied, simple but pleasant.

473ml can. Gorgeous pour, its dark brown with a thick and creamy tan-colored head, a robust porter for sure. Aroma is herbal/perfumey, cocoa, mineral, touch metallic. Flavor is good, licoricey, cocoa, malt, hint of roast/smoke.Velvety mouthfeel. Its good.
Dark brown and thick foamy head. Rich roasty and mocha aroma. Full of flavors of chocolate, roasty, burnt caramel, espresso, spice. Full body

This pours a very dark brown color with a creamy brown head. Lots of rich robust aromas. This drinks really thick and flavorful unlike a lot of porters that are thin and watery. Lots of heavy flavors of roasted malts and caramelized ingredients but still finishes a little dry and thinner than a stout. Definitely word class!

Dark brown color with a hint of red when poured. Dark tan head. Started like a nitro head, now fairly dense and rocky. Tight lace. Toasted to lightly roasted malts, hints of grain, light pumpernickel and hints of cocoa. Light sweet start. Full onslaught of lightly roasted malt. This is not a working mans porter; this is a lets get ready to rumble porter. Hint of alcohol, smooth feel. Some licorice. Lightly biting in the finish and linger, with a some spicy characteristics. Meaty in the finish. Somewhere in the abyss between a porter and a Baltic porter.

Approximately 8 oz. from a 16 oz. can, consumed on 4-9-16. Pours a dark brown with a moderate amount of dark taupe to grayish tan head. Sweet, malty, pleasant smell. Brown sugar scent. Coffee flavor. Sweet upon multiple sips. Simple but above average flavor for the style. Nice, roasted taste. Soft in the palate. Medium body. Overall, decent but boring. Nothing special, contra the reviews here.

Alot of Chocolate smells and tastes with this Porter. Malty backbone with hints of Carmel. Very drinkable for a beer being at 8% or 8.5% dangerously drinkable. Nice lacing on the side of the glass. Beautiful tan head that stays with the beer till the end sip. Sits really well on the palate ( no harshness) Appearance is almost black maybe very dark brown in color still has that beautiful lacing going on. A very drinkable, maybe too drinkable for a Porter. The only problem its only available in Wisconsin and it comes in a 4 pack of 16 oz cans. Make a 6 pack of 16oz cans for this Porter. 5 stars

16oz can, four pack. Deep opaque black-brown body, creamy beige head. Exceeded my expectations, this is a pretty big, full bodied porter for sure. Big chocolate, caramel, some toffee. Doughy mouthfeel. Really good.

Can pours a dark brown/black with a large dark brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, molasses, and a hint of licorice. Taste of rich chocolate and molasses, nice earthy roast, chocolate coats palate to the end with bitter hop spice on the finish. Solid all the way around!

16 oz can. Deep brown with a big brown head. Big roasted malt aroma with notes of chocolate, light alcohol and graham cracker. Light sweetness with a dry roasty flavor. Body is heavier with a clingy feel.
Very good. Cocoa, roast, black malt, bit of cereal for flavor. Aroma is cocoa, malt, molasses.

16oz can from Casanova. Not too sweet. Espresso/caramel mix with light
chocolate. Solid in the not-sweet side of the house. 14.2

(can) Had this awhile back in growler form, but now trying it out of the new cans. Pours jet black with a large dark tan head that lingers. Aroma right away is a pleasant mixture of roasted peanuts and chocolate that yields an olfactory effect of peanut butter cups. Some dark roasted coffee as well (probably Sumatran considering the peanut scent). The case could be made for mocha as well. This smells solid, but there are a few little unwanted pops of smoked meat scents (bacon) that crop up which interrupt the sweet decadence going on the aroma. The flavor is a huge slap of chocolate covered espresso bean (definite mocha vibes here), dark fruit (thinking plum/prune), roasted malt, and salted peanut that leads to a finish of smoked meat that is immediately followed by a hit of nondeScript hops that add nothing flavorful to the mix and merely serve to break off the sweetness in the mid and fore palate. Overall this is just as good as I remember it being, and its certainly a plus to be able to purchase a growler-sized sample of this beer at what I assume to be a cheaper price than an actual growler, as nothing was lost during the manufacture and canning of this beverage. I will definitely buy this again.
Keg @ Barley Johns. Deep brown with a tight tan head. Chocolate, toast. Mellow coffee and cream. Taste is mildly bitter. Some char. Toast and cocoa. Chocolate syrup. Medium body, silky.
Draft at GTMW 2015. Deep brown color, tan to beige head with good retention and lacing. Aroma of toffee, chocolate, coffee, subtle smoke. Taste is creamy cocoa, coffee, dark fruit. Delicious.

Tap at brew pub; very dark brown pour with a tan head; sweet aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and vanilla with some hints of coffee; bittersweet flavor with the chocolate, roast coffee and vanilla; has bitter coffee finish; very nice porter

Tap - small tan colored foamy head, pitch black color, strong roasty malt aroma and flavor, fair coffee notes, mildly chocolatey, pretty smooth finish - not bad for a porter (which isn't necessarily my favorite type of beer) 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had on tap at brewhouse. 8oz pour smells of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt and is dark black with tan head. Sweetness and bitterness are perfectly balanced and the beer coats your mouth with big rich flavors of coffee and chocolate.This is a beast of a porter weighing in at over 8% but the rich malt flavors keep everything balanced perfectly.
Sample from Barley Johns (backlog). Pour is black with tan head, lots of roasted malts, smooth palate. Very solid, 8% boost helps as well.
Sampled on tap at Barley Johns. Pours a black color with tan head. Roasty, creamy, burnt, malty flavors. My favorite of the seven I sampled at Barley Johns.
Great malt sweet nose. Chocolate and cocoa.  Good mouth feel. The finish is so good. Just lingers with sweet chocolate
Gritty chocolate Porter. Rich and a slight bitter aftertaste.  Can really tags the dark roasted quality.
Great to try this base for the bigger Dark Knight.  Roasty malty goodness with a bit more earthly taste than comparables.

Sampled at the brewpub... Pours a deeper solid stouty hue, homogenous, and topped with a nice khaki tan head... Roasty chocolately nose accented by oats and grain... Semi-sweet roasted malt, chocolate, and cocoa. Smooth creamy mouthfeel with light carbonation. Fairly solid.

Tap @ Barley Johns. Pours a black appearance with a dark brown head. Nice dark chocolate, light anise, a bit burnt aroma. Roasty/burnt, smore, charred chocolate, vanilla flavor. A little syrupy with lots of anise on the finish. A bit strong.

on tap at BJ, again with the solid beers, they have solid beers, none have been home runs all are very solid,  very smooth very balanced this beer nails the porter.. needs some more sweetness to me to make it really fantastic

Has a really nice chocolate scent with a big coffee roast. Taste is big coffee flavors with a little booze kick. Has a super nice lasting head.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Barley Johns. Pours viscous black, medium thick dark tan head, great lacing. Nose is smoky chocolate and rich earth notes. Sweet vanilla a bit here too, along with something "woodsy". Flavours of soft tart black malt, some mocha, some graphite/mineral. Really solid Porter.

Date: November 26, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Barley Johns Brew Pub Description: Opaque black pour, tan head with great lacing, smoky roasted and dark chocolate in the aroma and taste, slight bitter finish, medium to full bodied and smooth.
On tap at Barley Johns. Dark brown colour. Sweet, thin, chocolate and coffee.
Sampled this at ABR.  A very dark beer with thick creamy head.  Aroma is full of malty goodness!  Taste is much the same... pick some up!
on tap at the brewery pours black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is big roast and coffee.  Flavor is rich burnt sugar, roast, coffee and a nice bitter cocoa finish.  Really well done porter.

On tap at the brew pub into tasting glass...A dark brown, almost bordering black. Light tan head with good retention and lacing...A roasty aroma that is nice, but I really wish it was stronger...The taste is really sweet, didnt see that coming at all, a little too sweet but smooth.

An average porter but worth trying as its one of the better regulars available.

Growler to snifter. Oily black brown pour with a awesome quick tan head that fades to a collar. Aroma is roasted malt and bitter bakers chocolate and day old coffee. Taste is more bitter chocolate and roasted malt and maybe alittle dark fruit. Palate is medium to full feel and is oily slick and finishes dry. Awesome strong porter!

finally got in on a growler of this; thanks skinnyguy!!  pours dense brown and mostly flat on first pour; body is kind of flat and still; thin flavor of chocolate, mild roast, more body on the second pour as carbonation comes alive; roast, bakers chocolate, creamy milky coffee; damn good sweet nose of roast and sweet chocolate; whats up with the gunk?  Second and third samples are so much better; chocolate, light roast, yummy texture; damn good impy porter

On tap at the brewpub. Poured black with a dark brown head that dissipated slowly to the edges with a slight lacing. Aroma was full of roasted malt with some dark grains and just a bit of light fruit. Flavor was similar with roasted malt and dark grain with some light fruit coming out in the finish.

Nose of dark roasted malts, coffee, soft dark fruity sweetness, a good dose of floral and lightly fruity citrus hops. Pours black with a beige ring, some drippy lace, decent looking. Flavors of dark roast, dark chocolate, coffee, earth, nicely bitter hops. Dry, bitter, earthy. A little oddly yeasty in the finish at times becomes oddly mossy or something and it detracts lightly, most likely due to the 1inch cake of yeast in the growler, but still a nice beer.

Appearance: fairly deep black; plum and grape skin hues. Clear along bottom and sides of glass. Khaki and cream head and equally tinged lace. Lingers with a thin film.

Nose: dry, roasted, and brittle char. Burnt toast and wood; ash. Caramel nougat slightly burnt and caramelized along the edges. Burnt chocolates. Black cacao.

Palate: smooth and creamy which was not hinted at by her nose. Long on the roasted finish with dry chocolates, cacao beans, and ash. Nice. Hint of burnt cream in the middle. Vanilla root is subtle and not always present. Gentle roasted bitterness throughout. Medium body.

Final Thoughts:  a solid sessionable porter. The right amount of roast with complimentary flavors. Another straightforwardly good beer from the fine folks at Barley Johns.

Sample at the brewpub on 10/30/10. Pitch black pour with a huge light brown head. Roasty nose with dark fruit and dark chocolate. Flavor starts with dark fruit, then moves to bittersweet dark chocolate and finishes with a huge amount of bitter roast. Very good stuff.

On draft at the brewpub. Black in colour with moderate carbonation. Classic aromatic combo for a porter, with balanced notes of dark roasted malt, caramel, and chocolate. More dark chocolate in the mouth, along with coffee, smokey roast, mild caramel, and multi-grain bread. Medium bodied, with a zippy bitter finish. Very well executed.
on tap, balck brown colored pour with no head, excellent aroma of roast grain, whiskey and coffee, flavor is lighly boozy woth malty chocolate and coffee, waffles, nice finish

growler courtesy of arminjewell, thanks a ton! pours black with a small dark brown head that leaves nice lacey patterns on the surface the whole way through. aroma is roasty with a bright yeast profile, the taste is a solid, classic porter, no frills or special ingredients here. like they say, just a solid old school porter. good stuff, must be nice to have this as your local swil.

Pours deep brown/black with creamy tan head, aroma is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt.  Nice rich mouthfeel leads to a chocolate, coffee start with a nice roasted and bitter finish.  One of the better porters Ive had, nice flavors and balanced.

At Brewpub:  Dark brown pour with a finger of creamy brown head.  Light bits of lacing.  Roasty aroma is backed with a light cocoa sweetness.  Tastes roasty, yet sweet.  Chocolate, vanilla, and licorice.  Not at all dry from the heavy roast.  Smooth and creamy.  Just a little sweeter in the taste than I prefer, but still quite good.

Pours a deep, oily black with a thin, brown head. Aroma is dry with hints of roasted malts, chocolate, nuts, and some sweet fruit scents. Taste is also roasty with more malts, nuts, chocolate, plums, nuts, and some coffee with the alcohol masked very well. Thin to medium body, though it is much thinner than I anticipated, and low carbonation level. Very tasty porter.
Strong porter. Black pour with nice dark tan head--almost oily looking and tasting. Strong Chocolate and coffee aroma. A first-rate porter.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2009 Pint on tap.  Dark brown pour with a foamy tan head.  Heavy chocolate aroma with some coffee notes.  Flavor is slightly sweet chocolate with roasted coffee coming through.  Sweet, slightly smokey finish, amazingly good beer.

On tap at GTMW.  Poured deep brown with a rich cap of tan head.  The aroma opened with sweet roasted caramel and English toffee notes paired with a little vanilla.. the expected chocolate came on the back of the nose and was succulent.  The flavor found deeply-roasted chocolate and dark fruit at the core surrounded by a dry, spicy bitterness.. toasty finish.  Medium-bodied and dry on the palate with a fine mouthfeel.  I could drink a lot of this.

GTMW 2009: Deep brown hue with a small frothy tan head. The aroma has notes of toasty and nutty malts, chocolate, fig, plum and coffee. The taste is twangy fruits and chocolate with an dry ashy and nutty finish. A hint of coffee and anise is also found within. The mouth feel is lush and oily. A solid strong porter where the alcohol is well hidden.

On tap at the brewpub in New Brighton, Mn. Pours jet black black with a thick khaki colored head that leaves excellent lacing. Heavy aroma of fresh black earth, roasted coffee and chocolate. Flavor is chock full of chocolate, bitter coffee, fresh topsoil and a back end of licorice and roasted marshmallows. Thick, rich creamy mouthfeel, Best porter I have had in a long time.

On tap at the brewpub today.  Dark black pour, little carbonation and a nice roasted chocolate nose.  Flavor was creamy chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla and finished a little boozy (but not overpowering).

Tap at the brewpub. Dark black with abrown head. Dry roasty aroma, slightly sweet, a little chocolate. More chocolate in the flavor, some coffee and a little dry, lots of coffee in the finish. Pretty damn good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 TAP: black pour with a tan head. Aroma of roast, chocolate, and a faint amount of smoke. Roasted malt palate - very nice porter.

On tap at Barley Johns on 05/26/2009. Dark black body with a medium creamy light brown head. Roasty chocolate aroma with some bitterness. Sweet roast, caramel and chocolate flavor. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.

A very interesting beer.  Served cold from tap and initially had no aroma.  Initial flavor was of a simple, easy drinking porter.  As warmed, more and more coffee, some sweet chocolate and burnt wood came out in the aroma and flavor became more complex.  I waited so long for it to warm that I end up late and had to run without really savoring.  Must try again.  Why not a growler with friends?

Winterfest 2009 - Pours a deep dark brown with a fluffy tan head. The nose consisted of heavily roasted chocolate and coffee. Comes across the palate as charred malts, strong coffee, chocolate, caramel, and some alcohol. A relatively light porter.

Bottle generously shared with Sparky27.  Eric, you da man!!!  Ive never smelled anything quite as sublime as this in a beer.  I inhaled deeply, my nostrils filling with Hersheys milk chocolate, Nestle Quik, and Cocoa Puffs.  Also present were Kona, Columbian, and Brazilian coffee beans; dark and heavily roasted.  The aroma was truly heavenly.  This was onyx in color with a small caramel colored head that left without lacing the glass.  Extremely charred, ashy flavor...like a smores by the campfire.  Might have lost a little because it was hand bottled but still a DAMN FINE BEER!!!

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2009 Hand bottle courtesy of Guerde  thanks Andy!  Pours a pitch black with minimal tan head that fades into a ring around the glass.  The nose is decadent chocolate, roasted coffee beans and toasted malt. The taste is charred malt, burnt coffee, ashy cocoa and light hops in the finish.  Medium, semi-creamy mouth feel.  Very good porter.  Thanks again Andy!

In short: A smooth creamy chocolaty porter.  Nothing groundbreaking but this is an above average example of the style.
How: Hand-bottle from MatSciGuy.  Huge thanks Levi for this special treat.  Consumed fresh a week after receiving it.
The look: Black body topped by a small tan head
In long: The very nice nose is heavily focussed black coffee with some chocolate cake in the back.  In mouth its the other way around with the black cake dominating the roasted coffee beans.  The smooth and round rich chocolaty maltiness is really more akin to a chocolate cake than pure bitter black chocolate.  Low hops presence.  The high roastiness develops into astrigency.  The body was a bit lifeless but Im not gonna take away any points since I was drinking from a homemade hand-bottled that had travelled from Minnesota to Montreal.  This was an unexpected nice surprise to get this hand-bottle out of the blue that I couldnt get otherwise since Im never out of the blue, Im always in the red.

Pours a syruppy black from the tap at the brewery with a trim brown head.  Smells of brown sugar with a woody taste that features bakers cocoa and mild smoke.  Earthy for a porter.  Hops are all over the front of the palate.  Watery sap and barley also seem present.

Hand Bottle at home ... thanks to Stine and BDR for this ... deep black light tan head ... very soft ... light carbonation (but it  is a hand bottle) ... light toasted oat and roast malt nose ... big chocolate smootrh soft roast ... light coffee light biterness ... good body ... for me much better than the DKR.

Growler shared by theisti in March ’08. Aroma is malty and chocolatey, with roasted malt,  to a lesser extent. Thick mouthfeel. Flavor is dark chocolate, light roast, earthy and herbal hops. Ashy finish.
Slightly smoky. Caramel that is not so good. Excellent finish. Some good hop bitterness in there. Some chocolate but not a whole lot.

[Tap] Poured a really nice ruby brown with a bit of rocky tan head. Aroma is baker’s chocolate, roasted barley, and a touch of hops. Mouthfeel is very smooth and quite drinkable. Lots of roasted barley with a little bit of chocolate on the finish. Very solid porter.

Good brew, aroma of coffee and roasted, toasted malts, hints of chocolate.  Appearance is dark brown, thin tan head.  Flavors of roasted coffee beans and roasted malt and hints of barley.  Palate is smooth and clean finish.  Overall, the best of the Barley Johns I tried and a good brew.

Santa 2007 Rocks!!! He Rocks!!! 
Smoky, roasty, chocolate and coffee aroma. Basic, and without any nuance that would increase my enjoyment of the aroma. The body is deep black and holds a very nice looking, thumb thick, mocha head. Astringent. Bitter, bittersweet chocolate, cream, decent alcohol kick....standard chocoff. Creamy thick mouthfeel. Dark chocolate bitter on the whole with a nice dark fruit highlight.

hand bottle from stine... opaque dark brown nearly black pour with a thin light brown head and spotty lacing. big cheesy creamy aroma followed by chocolate, dark roasty grain and coffee. the flavor is roasty and not too sweet combined with more coffee, dark chocolate, grain astringency, cream and grassy herbal hops. sourness on the finish. medium to full bodied but astringency keeps in easy to drink. 

no one has mentioned the cheese character in this which leads me to believe its somewhat infected? maybe im just hypersensitive to it? idk.  strangely though, it works... still, id love to try this fresh! thanks eben for taking down another from my list!

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 Wow, what a delicious beer. Aside from the Olfabrikken, this might be my new favorite porter. Deep, oily dark brown with a big fluffy tan head. Bittersweet roasted malt/chocolate aroma. Upon taking a sip, the bitter roasted malts and coffee notes hit the tongue first and then fade out into a delicious, lingering chocolate finish. Thick, full-bodied mouthfeel. Very smooth. I wanted to order about ten more after I finished my first. This is a great beer.

On tap at Barley Johns and served in an English pint glass.  This beer poured a deep, dark brown with a lasting head of fluffy tan foam.  Lots of nice lacing.  The aroma of the beer was made up of heavily roasted chocolate and coffee, along with a hint of alcohol.  The flavor consisted of burnt malts, strong coffee, chocolate, caramel, and some warming alcohol.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and smooth with very light carbonation.  A very nicely made porter.

From a growler at DLD - Pours very dark brown with a thin tan head.  The aroma is of dark roast malt accented with coffee.  The flavor has the dark roast malt with coffee and chocolate notes thats typical of this style.  It has a robust body and is quite good, but didnt seem quite as impressive to me as the ratings show.

12 oz handbottle.  Dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Nose of coffee beans, grape and mocha.  Medium light with a mild carb tang.  Taste is coffee and chocolate with hints of prune and blueberry.  Woody drying with a tobacco aftertaste.  Solid.

Handbottle from stine - thanks!  This one pours to a beautiful roasty black with a smaller head.  Aroma is thick and roasty - lots of chocolate, some coffee, and some sweet scents.  Flavor is big, roasty and sweet - Darker chocolate and coffee abounds with light hop bitterness.  Very smooth and tasty.  Really good - cant wit to try the dark knight based on this experience.

Handbottle trade extra from Stine, which was a very generous gesture.  Black in color with a small brown head that dissipates into a ring around the side of my unibroue tulip.  Aroma: chocolate, some light raisin, roast and caramel malts, and light floral/pine hop notes.  Taste is nice and chocolate driven, with roast, raisin.  A medium caramel body which is perfect for big porter.  Finishes with a touch of alcohol, lingering roast, chocolate, and some hop bitterness. Thanks Eben!

Pretty declicious brew.  Dark pour with long lasting dark tan head.  Aroma of light burntness.  Taste was very light dark fruit, roasted malt, and was real smooth and creamy.  Seemed like a pretty simple porter but a job well done.  Would buy again.
scent of burntness.  long lasting head.  taste is very very smooth with a finish of burnt nuts.  a very good porter.

Growler shared by theisti at csbosoxs tasting, on 3/7/08. Pours black with an oily surface and a thin mocha ring around the edge of the glass. The nose is a blend of fruit, cocoa and roast malt. Fairly light-bodied and thin with almost no carbonation and a dry roasty finish. Coffee, bright fruit (plum), light chocolate and roasted malt. A solid porter that Id love to try fresh some day. Thanks for sharing this one with us, Tim.
Growler shared by theisti.  Opaque dark brown with a brown and reddish head.  Aroma of iced coffee and berries.  Cocoa and coffee flavors.  Hefty body yet quaffable.  Very good stuff.

Growler, courtesy of my sister and brother in law (part of an extremely generous six pack of MN Growlers), shared at the csbosox tasting on 3/7/08.  Pour is deep-brown, slick black with a smallish tan head that goes away fast.  Aroma of roast malt, and a slight earthy grassy smell in the background.  Taste of roasted / brewed coffee, with some hop bitterness to the finish.  Really solid, well made Porter.

Growler shared with and courtesy of Degarth. For some reason I kept calling this one Hard Eight Porter in my head. Then I remembered it was a beer, not a Janet Evanovich novel. Pour is black as night, completely opaque and very viscous. Huge creamy mocha head settles on top and has incredible retention and lasting. Resolves to a layer of thick foam atop the beer. Looks like an Imp Stout. Nose of BBQ smoke, tobacco leaves, cocoa powder, dark malts, licorice, molasses and dark fruity esters. Flavor profile is similar, but adds in a good amount of hoppy bite and roasty bitterness. Medium bodied, very creamy mouthfeel. Huge, lengthy finish is heavily astringent, then in turns bitter and sweet before trailing off. Astringency is almost overwhelming for the first few sips, but it either fades as the beer breathes or you become numb to it. Great porter.

Draft ABR.  Poured a nice deep black with a tan head.  Nice smokey roasted malt on the nose as well as chocolate.  Nice medium bodied beer that lets the roasted malt and chocolate dominate.  A very nice porter.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Draft @ Brewpub: Black, tawny brown head, nose of sweet smoky plum, wooden grainy plum and sweet herbal hops. The flavor is clean and balanced, mocha and juniper. Nice, thoroughly hopped.

[Draft, ABR 07] Pours black with a nice brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt.  Taste is the same but the coffee is more pronounced and chocolate is more subtle--also there is some bitterness in there.  Long finish.  Not quite as good as I remembered.

Date: 06/23/2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewpub

opaque brown, fine tan head, spidery lace, 
rich chocolate aroma with a mixture of dark and milk chocolates, 
velvet body, 
rich chocolate flavor that lasts and lasts, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 10/10; Overall: 17/20
Rating: 4.1/5.0Drinkability: 9/10
Score: ***+/4

This pours almost black with a brown oily head.  Very roasty (read:burnt) caramel, chocolate, espresso, smoke, and dark grains.   The texture was creamy and mouth-coating.  Big abv was well-hidden but detectable.  One of the best porters Ive had in recent months.   Very fine brew.
Draft. Deep brown. Good lacing. Toasted malt and chocolate with a dusty element. Chalky texture. Warmth of big alcohol.

RBSG 07 pubcrawl. A dark almost black pour with a deep tan lacing. A flavor of burnt coffee laced with rich dark chocolate. The palate was just a tad foamy to me but the full rich flavor and smooth palate carry the palate back to the score of 4. A beer that would work as a desert for almost any occasion.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2008 I tried on tap again recently and gave it the exact smae numbers. From a grolwer, thanks iowaherkeye. The body was black with an orange and tan head. The aroma was highly roasted with some caramel and dark chocolate. There was also a fresh soybean character. The taste was rich chocolate with some soybeans. The light coffee was in the background. Definitely a robust porter with all the roast character. Nicely done and hard to believe that this is 8%.

Draft RBSG 07 This beer rocks!...  Pitch black with a mid-sized, creamy, light brown head and great retention. Chocolaty, woodsy nose provides lots of milk chocolate, oak and vanilla no preview of the tannins and hops to come. The flavor starts off sweet, but very well-roasted. This is followed up by tons of burnt, caustic malts and heavily bitter hops. Full-bodied with modest carbonation. Odd, but appetizing, tangy, bitter finish.

Sample from tap at the brewpub. Pours balck with creamy chocolate head. Aroma is roasted malt. Flavour is roasted dry malt, going into a coffee bitterness which becomes reasonable strong. Again a dry beer and with elements of dried fruit without becoming sweet.
RBSG 2007 Pub Crawl: Poured black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, chocolate, coffee. Flavor, roasted malts, chocolate, some coffee bitterness. Good stuff.
RBSG 07- on tap at brewpub.  The whole place smelled a little smokey, so I dont know if it was really smokey or not.  Pours dark brown, toffee and chocolate taste.  Burning finish.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: RBSG 07- on tap at brewpub.  Pours a deep brown almost black with ruby highlights, chocolate aroma, charred wood, light smoke and hints of roast coffee.  Good smooth flavor loaded with tons of chocolate malt, roast, fruits, toffee, nutty and toasty- light licorice and tar in the end.  Great Porter.
Dark brown colour with a thick tan head that died away quickly. Burnt/roasted malt aroma and a bit of chocolate. The flavour was also filled with burnt malts ending in a dry bitter finish.

On tap at the Barley Johns brewpub, pours a clear dark brown brew with a fast disolving tan head. Aroma of chocolate, smoked wood, and some dark pipe tobacco. Flavor is full bodied, smooth, creamy with a burnt sweet/bitter finish.
Dry malt nose with a faint sweetness to it.  Vaguely chocolate nose and taste with a dry flavor.

Draft at the brewpub.  Aroma:  Big roasted malt aroma with notes of espresso, cocoa, toasted nuts, and anise.  Some slight dark fruit and yeast as it warms up.  Appearance:  Dark brown in color with very small walnut highlights.  Light tan head was small and foamy with decent retention.  Fair lacing.   Flavor:  This is definitely a robust porter.  Big roasted maltiness with a lot of espresso and cocoa.  Getting some toasted nuts, caramel, and a large note of anise, too.  Finishes fairly dry with a little bit of roasted malt astringency.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  Great porter.  Really chewy and with a ton of roasted malt character.  Really enjoyed it.

Thanks to Ty5592 for a hand bottle of this.  Pours onyx with 1-finger brown head.  Aroma of huge roasty dark malt, rich chocoff, molasses, almond, some prune.  Tastes roasty and richly malty, with a big chocolate syrup element, plus coffee, molasses, ovaltine, and some hops.  Pretty dense palate with a lot of complexity.

Growler from footbalm, WHAT!?!! Black with small lacing type tan head. Has a brown hue to it. Very robust aroma of expresso, roasted malt, and semi sweet chocolate. The taste was the same with a strong roasted character. Medium body but very smooth, silky in fact. Strong coffee finish. I posted a ISO for this in the forum section and not one person responded. Eric sent an email stating he could get this anytime....Im very grateful for that, Thanks Eric.

Growler from Footbalm! - Thanks Eric! - Pours black with a short tan head that faded back pretty quick.  Robust aromas of chocolate, roasted malts,  and expresso.  Flavor is expresso, chocolate, roasted malts, some slight dark fruit, and a little coffee.  Slight carbonation but pretty full in body with a somewhat dry roasty finish..  Nice porter and one that I could drink every day were it available..

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2007 Draft @ BP.  A very nice, drinkable, strong porter.  Very robust and chocolatey.  Smooth finish. Coffee notes.  Cool malty presence.  Distint malt that I havent noticed in other porters/stouts.

Pours a very dark brown with half an inch or so a deep tan head. Decent head retention and lacing. Full aroma - lots of chocolate, coffee,and roasted grain.

Lots of bittersweet chocolate malt in the flavor, very tasty. Strong espresso and roasted grain in there as well. An earthy dryness shows up in the finish.

Almost full bodied, softly but fully carbonated.
Porters are becoming my fav style after having ones like this. Now having had the Left Hand Porter, Sumiits Porter and this one, they are all top notch. Chocaltey coffee taste makes me want more!
superb porter had it on tap just superb all around roasted malts chocolate etc mm tasty

Growler, via joebrew.  Pours a completely pitch black colored body under a frothy dark brown head.  Good retention with some light lacing.  Aroma is very roasty with some burnt malt, licorice, espresso, and a dry chalky yeasy undercurrent.  Flavor is roasty and chocolaty with alot of burnt chalkiness, especially on the finish.  Very robust for a Porter.  Mouthfeel is full bodied and rather thick with moderate fizzy carbonation.  A little sticky on the finish.  A pretty darn good beer, extremely robust, and really pushing the envelope of what is a Porter.

Beer pours black with a totally retained tan head.  Aroma is very roasted with a decent hop note to back it up.  Flavor is nice roasted malt flavor, a bit acrid, burnt, but not too much so.  Easy going palate.  Good.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2008 This is a unique and memorable porter.  Beautiful creamy tan head that stays. Chocolate, black licorice, and blackberry flavors take precedence over roasted and black malt.  Sweet, savory light-roasted coffee flavor is a nice surprise.  Still, even with the intimidating black hue, the full, rich flavor palate and the high ABV, this is not a difficult climb of a beverage.  Its like a rewarding view without the hike (so its both immediately gratifying and a bit dangerous). 

Rerate.  No updated notes, but a simple disclaimer that several recent kegs have been pretty diacetyl heavy.
Sampler at pub.  Nice chocolaty taste with a bit of coffee and nuts. A  Nice Porter.  Just a bit grainy
On tap at pub. Interesting coffee aroma. Coffee and smoky chocolate flavor.
Tap at brewpub. Opaque with a thick ring of bubbles. Light tannins, wood, chardonnay, nuts, and butter. Dry finish. Lots of dry woody flavors. Muted nose.

Thanks to hopdog for opening the growler...
Appears black with a 1/2" tan head that slowly fades. Tons of scattered lacing is left around the glass.
Smell is of bitter chocolate, dark fruit, and even a light whiff of banana somewhere in there.
Taste is that of a porter that is rich with chocolate, cream, truffels, and a touch of dark fruit.
Mouthfeel is a little rough around the edges but has some smooth, creamy, rich chocolate and sweetness.

Growler sample courtesy of hopdog. Deep rusty brown body with a fast-fading tan head. Nice aroma of rum raisin, dark chocolate and red wine. Medium roast and nice chocolate flavor with lots of black cherry character and some light sour fruit. An excellent porter in my book.

Growler acquired in trade with kms399 (thanks!). Poured a dark black with red edges and a smaller sized light brown head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, lactose, vanilla, and some wood. Tastes of chocolate, coffee, wood, and light smoke. Smooth body. I glad I had a chance to try this one!

Poured a dark mahogany color with a small, light tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, and vanilla.  Taste of sweet chocolate, light smoke, and a dry roastiness in the finish.
Thanks to hopdog for landing this growler for the midweek tasting.  Pours a dark, dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate and lactose.  Flavor of dark chocolate and coffee.
A really big beer!  Not a wimpy porter.  Hershy Dark color, heavy chocolate & espresso.  A head you need an axe to cut through!.  One of the greats!  Available by the glass or growler.

St. Paul Winterfest 06. An adult milkshake. Big, thick and chocolaty with ample roastiness. Very much like a rich sweet stout. No off tastes whatsoever to get in the way of this dark, thick dessert beer.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2008 On tap: May 06. Opaque black color with huge beige head. aroma is full of chocolate, roasted grain and faint coffee. Light hop background. Flavor has a nice buttery chocolate character to it, some roast through the middle and nice lingering hop bitterness for balance. Somewhat slick/oily mouthfeel.

Growler:  Courtesy of robertsreality via trade.  Huge roasted coffee aroma with slight hints of chocolate.  Pours a dark brown with no transparency and a moderate tan head that lasts a minute or so.  Like aroma, the flavor is loaded with roasted coffee.  Light dark chocolate in the background.  Cafe mocha finish fades to a black coffee aftertaste.  Chocolate presence increases slightly as you drink.
Black body, tan head, nice lacing. Aroma is medium sweet, chocolate, roasty, light cherry.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, roasty, alcohol well hidden.  Smooth, medium-full body.

dark black well laced tan head.  Smells hot of some alchol roasted malt semi sweet chocolate & vanilla.  Palate is a bit light, well coated and lightly sticky  Flavor is a very well roasted malt hints of vanilla & chocolate.  Overall good stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2005 On tap at Barley Johns.  The beer has a beige bubbly head atop a dark black body.  Excellent lacing.  The aroma is really light.  Coffee and chocolate notes.  Oatmeal?  If this beer had some aroma it would be much better.  The flavor has tons of coffee and espresso.  Dark bitter chocolate.  The palate is medium bodied and allows the flavor to linger.

Tap @ GTMW.  Opaque coffee black color with a deep tan foamy head.  Woodsy aroma accentuated by milk chocolate, dark chocolate and Milky Ways.  Nice creamy dark chocolate flavor.  Mocha and caramel macchiato elements add depth and dimension.  Loving the palate feel.  Some dark cigar wrappers and coffee beans, along with caramel ribbons running through fudge brownies.  Deep espresso roast resonates in the finish.  Solid.

Pours a robust dark opaque with a thick, lightly-lacing tan head.  Aroma is dry and roasty with some smokiness.  Body starts with a nice malty thickness, an earthy palate, and some dry smoke.  A nice, easy drinking porter at least compared to the Dark Knight.

Dark, good lasting head, light brown with attractive sheeting.  Big malty nose, light roasts, some boubon, sweet and strong.  Excellent flavor, very roasty, plenty of coffee bitterness, very hoppy at the end.  Slightly woody.  Nice porter.
Tap @ brewpub.  Black color with a dark brown head.  Toasted malts and lots of chocolate.  Nice and robust.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2006 Gitchee Gumee Brewfest 2005. Im not usually a fan of Porters, because they seem a little watery and weak, but this one has body and backbone. Aromas of rich chocolate. Strong flavors of more swiss chocolate and a good dose of dark pipe tobacco and strong birch wood smoke. I would drink this all the time. Finishes a little too dryly though, if there were a little more sweetness in the smack and finish, this would be out of this world!
10 w. 30 in color.  with a light head.  Smokey chocolate and coffe characterize this with a definite hop profile.  Finishes lightly bitter, but very smooth.  Very good.
Holy hops, Batman! Slightly carbonated, dark dark brown, sweet malts.  It hopped the heck out of my tongue, but I would definitely try it again. Tasty and chewy, well done.

Im drinking this from a growler courtesy of Badgerben and Robertsreality (thanks guys!). Pours deep brown with a bit of almost-as-deep brown head that dissipates rather quickly. Nose is mild with a smooth roast character and some oxidative sherry notes (probably from storage in a growler but actually quite nice in this case, it almost tastes aged). Flavor is loaded with big, dark malts and its definitely big  but above all things this beer is smooth. Like, crazy smooth--just a touch of bitterness, some chocolate, a faint vinous tartness and the slightest whisper of alcohol. Carbonation is subdued but the flavor is interesting enough that it doesnt come across as flat. Really a nice porter. I could see myself drinking this all the time if it was local.

From the session that included dark knight, the O-fest, this and Big Nick, only this and Big Nick distinguished themselves as a beer to truly seek out.  Dark opaque with mocha head.  Light fruit muted on the nose.  Big body with a nice burnt toast flavor.  Good creamy quality that would suggest a cream stout, but since none of his beers I have tasted are catagorically specific, I wont rate negatively upon this.

Dark black/brown w/mocha head. Molasses, chocolate, and sour milk on the nose. Heavy weight with a bitter chocolate finish. Flavors of chocolate, milk, carmel, and faint hops.  Rich and tasty though nore like a stout in some ways.
A thick and heavy porter.  Sweeter than many porters, flavors of oatmeal, coffee, and chocolate.

On tap,ABR.Pitch black wityh just a bit of dark tan foam.I havent had this in a while and I guess I had forgotten how good it was.Roasted malt qualities along  chocolate expresso tones make this darn tasty brew.if this was bottled,it would be a staple in my fridge.
Liquorice and roast aroma.  Heavily smoky with considerable roast component.  Strong-alcohol is definitely felt here.  Long roasty finish.
Tan creamy and lasting head. Dark brown/black body. Rich and full chocolatey aroma. Smokey chocolate taste with a light coffee bitter finish. Very good stuff.
UPDATED: AUG 22, 2005 Black body, tan creamy head.  Roasty chocolate aroma.  Nice grassy hops in the flavor.  Otherwise theres waffles, plummy oak and the requisite roasty coffee bean flavor.
Black Coloring.  Roasts, Malt.  Bitter.  Roasted Coffee... Very Enjoyable Beer.  Damn Fine Porter!

Very black color.  Slight coffee on the nose which comes out more in the taste.  It tastes and smells more like a heavily roasted coffe than just coffee.  Good malt character and unsweetened chocolate.  Quite tasty.

Sample at the brewpub.  Totally opaque, silky-looking and gleaming, with a thick brown lasting meringue head.  Roasty, coffee-toffee nose; sharp, bitter flavor profile which smooths out a bit and develops some nice sweet root-beery qualities near the end.

99% opaque, obviously rich in appearance, dark caramel cream head.  Creamy smooth palate.  Deep roasted flavors and a long bitterness.  The roasted flavors are almost too much after a bit.  Nice though not unchallenging.

Appearance: fully black, near-opaque, with a short, yet substantial head above, toasty tan. Aroma: roasty, peppery, notes of anise, and bittersweet espresso, and chocolate.
Gritty, earthy taste, solid, rich character, loaded with malt, just a whiff of hoppiness, full-bodied. Easily drinkable, despite the higher-than-normal ABV. A very pleasurable porter, indeed.
I was just getting used to this one, when along came the waitress, unbidden, with free samples of Alfreds Porter, their step above, weighing in at 14%!
Ill try a full sample of that, next time, if I can, but Ill look forward to this every visit!

Color is very, very dark solid brown, nearly black with a thin tannish-cocoa brown head that fades to a thin ring and small sheets of lacing. Smell is a good sense of dark roastyness and chocolate with a good coffee backing which seems to pick up and become more evident as it warms. Taste comes across way to soon and very uneven of coffee, chocolate and bittering hops, very unbalanced, almost enough for it to be enjoyable. The alcohol of 8% makes an appearance far to soon and is what really makes the flavors falter, it seems to get in the way of any taste.The finish is tolerable with light lingering dark fruits and sweet malts. Its overbearing in the start making this very hard to enjoy or finish. The richness trying to poke through is bogged down by uneven chocolaty bitterness that just never settles or shines like a good chocolate should and the coffee flavor seems like its a week old in pot with only about an inch of liquid left in it. Didn't like this one, seems like it could be better, perhaps next time I'm in at Barley John's I'll try it again sense it is a year round tap.
Winterfest St. Paul 2/8/03.  I liked her, she surprised me with her "sista" appearance.  She tasted good.  WAWOOD and I doubled teamed her.

One of the top brews offered at Winterfest in St. Paul, MN on Feb. 8. Faint alcohol aroma with hints of chocolate. Completely opaque. Served extremely cold; probably too cold for a porter. Flavorful and rich; alcohol was not too overwhelming. Very excellent.
